headline.print_headline: Risks: Too Much Vitamin D May Backfire
headline.seo: Too Much Vitamin D May Backfire, Study Suggests
headline.main: Risks: When Too Much Vitamin D Is Too Much

docs.abstract: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University publish study in The American Journal of Cardiology finding that an excess of vitamin D can increase the levels of C-reactive protein in the bloodstream, which has been linked to cardiovascular disease.
docs.lead_paragraph: Vitamin D supplements reduce blood levels of an indicator of inflammation that is linked to cardiovascular disease. But too much can raise those levels.
docs.snippet: Vitamin D supplements reduce blood levels of an indicator of inflammation that is linked to cardiovascular disease. But too much can raise those levels.

headline.main: Risks: Too Much Vitamin D May Backfire

docs.abstract: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University publish study in The American Journal of Cardiology finding that an excess of vitamin D can increase the levels of C-reactive protein in the bloodstream, which has been linked to cardiovascular disease. (M)a
docs.lead_paragraph: Too much vitamin D may be just as bad as too little, a recent study suggests. Vitamin D supplements reduce blood levels of C-reactive protein, or CRP, an indicator of inflammation that is linked to cardiovascular disease. But supplements help only up to a point.
docs.snippet: Too much vitamin D may be just as bad as too little, a recent study suggests.      Vitamin D supplements reduce blood levels of C-reactive protein, or CRP, an indicator of inflammation that is linked to cardiovascular disease. But supplements help...

headline.main: Personal Health: Lifelines for People With Hearing Loss

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column offers advice on the proper treatment of hearing loss; notes the condition is currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, making it a contender for the nation's most damaging and costly sensory handicap. Drawing (M)1
docs.lead_paragraph: Hearing loss, a disability currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, may be the nation's most damaging and costly sensory handicap. It is a hidden disability, often not obvious to others or even to those who have it. Its onset is usually insidious, gradually worsening over years and thus easily ignored.
